I was asked to build an electronic component following a demo by the team member and I was able to do it quickly. The team member gave me compliments on completing the device as it usually takes a while if it;s being fabricated the first time. 
After the tour, I got a chance to interact with the person in charge of hiring and it lasted for about 20 minutes.  
The whole interview lasted for about 2 hours and I was told at the end that I would be having a quiz to complete along with the submission of 3 professional references.
Interview Questions: What is your 5 year plan ?

title: Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: Took many months. Job description changed in the middle of the process. Hiring managers didn't seem to know what was going on.  Surprised that the place is still functioning. Even after having received the job, there was no real onboarding procedure. No one really cared what happened to you after you get the job. They don't support you after you get hired. Might as well devote a % of your salary towards buying the support and supplies you need.  Full salary position and couldn't even get a decent computer for a month or two. No one even bothered to ensure that there was a working phone in my office.  Just expected me to pay for calls using my personal cell.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Boston, MA) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: I had 2 interviews. One was general and one involved giving a presentation on my PhD work.  The process was very quick and the main decision was the PI so I didn't worry about anything else.
Interview Questions: How did you solve this problem?

title: MITpostdoc Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions:
For postdoc you apply to a lab you interested in with some proposed research plan.
If the PI like the idea and interested you will go to present your previous work and visit the lab.
if everything goes well you may get an offer.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: Too long; didn't interview with actual decision makers.  The interview lasted over 3 hours.  Inefficient process.  Also, before 3 hour interview, they have you do an hour long phone interview.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself in 10 years?

title: Assistant Professor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 months. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: a phone screening, and then you gave a seminar, then another skype interview. The day you gave a seminar, you spend a whole day there, talking to a few professors, some of them ask you about your future research, some of them ask you tough questions.
Interview Questions: many many

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: It’s pretty straightforward and phone based. I was interviewed by one of the phd students working in the lab, who was very nice . I was asked about my lab and research experience.
Interview Questions: Have you worked in a lab before?

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Boston, MA) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: You apply online and rank the classes you want to teach.  From there, its up to you to go after and contact professors and see if they want you to help teach in the class or not.  Very relaxed, have to make sure to stay on top of the whole process.  Assuming you already got accepted into the masters of engineering school.
Interview Questions: Previous teaching experience, grade you got in the class.

title: Undergraduate Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: You can contact any professor whose research you are interested in or search through the listings on the UROP website and then contact the supervisor from there. After responding, the supervisor will probably set up a time for an interview so you guys can discuss your interests in the research and what you can contribute.  They will also make sure that you might all the requirements for the position and will probably ask you to send them a resume that you will discuss at the interview.
Interview Questions: What are your prior research experiences.

title: Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: A red flag should have been that the folks were very boring during the interview. Monotone voiced, uninteresting, could not make small talk. No one tried to engage me or get to know me.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Graduate Student Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: interview process was fairly straightforward. Met with several different professors who asked about previous research experience as well as research interests and goals. Not very behavioral. Just a summary of previous experiences.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your previous research experience.

title: Senior Reactor Operator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview for basic experience and level of knowledge. They want to know you're qualified and intelligent before they bother bringing you in. Once you're in the panel interview they ask about your experience, family, hobbies, etc. NRL is a small team so they need to know that you will fit in well personality wise with the other staff members. It is an intelligent, friendly team and they work closely together and depend upon each other to accomplish the tasks necessary.
Interview Questions: Tell us about your experience in training other personnel

title: Contractor Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: Smooth, efficient, and quick. Felt collaborative instead of interrogative. Questions were relevant to the position being applied to. Interviewer was warm and enthusiastic for the interview. Questions focused a lot on how to contribute to the community / role.
Interview Questions: How can you contribute to the community?

title: Administrative Assistant II Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at MIT in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: Very long and tiring, but worth it in the end since I accepted the job offer! I met with about 8 different people and interviewed with them each individually. Afterwards I spoke with the recruiter regarding the details and he negotiated an offer.
Interview Questions:
Went over the resume and past jobs/internships

Where do you see yourself in 5 years?

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at MIT (Boston, MA) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions:
Around 3-4 weeks after submitting the online application, they email you either saying you got the interview or not. If you did, there'll also be a link to the open time slots which you can choose from for the specified date. 

In the interview, the interviewer first asks you to walk through your CV then asks followup questions and after these goes to the behavioural questions part. These should be in past tense since they're looking for experiences not made up ideas. After 2-3 of these the interview is finished by your questions. I think you should definitely ask 1 or 2 to look interested. Mine was 40 minutes.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time where you had a conflict with someone and how you resolved it

title: Undergraduate Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: He basically just came in and made sure that I could contribute in some way to the project.  He knew that it would be a learning experience for me, so it was ok to learn some things on the job.  It was more of a first meeting than an interview in that sense; my resume and his demand for students pretty much got me the position.
Interview Questions: What do you want to work on?

title: Graduate Student Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: Submitted application, was invited to an interview weekend, spoke with professors and graduate students, all of whom evaluated me (including, yes the graduate students, even during social situations).  Acceptance email was delivered within a week of interview weekend.  Most applicants were accepted, with a few exceptions, mainly due to inappropriate behavior during social situations.
Interview Questions: Most questions were expected--describe research, etc.

title: Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and then waited 4-6 weeks. My manager emailed me to set up a phone interview for the next week. The phone interview was about 20 minutes and went well. She invited me in for an in-person interview by email the next day. The in person interview was with three people. I was asked to give a 10 minute presentation and then we had an interview portion where I was asked questions and was given time to ask questions in return. I was offered the job about a week later and salary negotiation lasted about a week after that. We set a start date of one month after the offer was given. All told the process was maybe 3 months long.
Interview Questions: They asked about working on a team. Collaboration is big here.

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at MIT (Boston, MA) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: Very thorough .Several round of open discussion.One needs to be thoroughly prepared for the subject. You need to be well read, informed and must have ability to articulate your own singular viewpoint . The process is very open discussion format.Since you are going to work on projects which have no reference in the world,it is appropriate that you need to be ready to become reference.
Interview Questions: What do you think about the future of X field ? What is your vision? Why do you think like that?

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at MIT in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: submit your application package, GRE scores, GPA, recommendation letters, SOP. Then you will probably get to interview with some faculty, and you receive your acceptance letter sometime between February and March.
Interview Questions: What is your research experience ?

title: Senior Staff Accountant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Dec 2014
Interview Descriptions: I applied for the job online and received a response back from HR within two days for an interview. I interviewed the following week with the associate director and supervisor for the department. After the interview it took three months to find out that the position hadn't been filled and that they were still looking at candidates to fill the role. It seemed that they were willing to wait for the perfect candidate.
Interview Questions:
What was the most important achievement during your career?
Why do you think you experience matches our job description?
Went over background.

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: I heard back very quickly and had an interview within the week. I was interviewed by the main heads of the department. The people were pleasant, but it took a long time to hear back after the interview.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Technical Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: Applied online directly through MIT job board. Was contacted about a month later and scheduled for a phone interview. Came in for 2 in person interviews and was told my desired salary was far above what they were able to offer for the position, though I also interviewed for a nearly identical position at another university in Cambridge that was willing to work to match my desired salary.
Interview Questions: Would you be willing to take on additional responsibilities beyond what is listed in the job description? This was asked during the same conversation where I was informed they were unable to make a competitive salary offer.

title: Fundraiser Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: For higher-level positions, expect to meet with at least 5 people, as well as the entire team (support staff). It will be a full day of meetings. You will be invited to a lunch, where you will be evaluated for your soft skills, personality, and ability to carry a sophisticated a conversation. Be prepared to talk about MIT news and things you might share with a donor.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time when you were given feedback that surprised you? What was the feedback and how did you handle it?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: Taken into the office and talked to about my accomplishments and goals. What I'd done in the past and what research I'd taken part in. Overall nothing too out of the ordinary. They did ask in detail about previous research.
Interview Questions: What did you do during the research period?

title: Development Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jul 2014
Interview Descriptions: Stiff and clinical, people at MIT Sloane are overly professional and have lost the human touch. One feels like one has to fit a mold, and any deviance from the accepted overworked, worker ant norm (even if you are doing your job well, and hitting all performance standards) is looked down upon.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work at MIT?

title: Graduate Resident Tutor Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: Basically you put in an application, went through a vetting process with the Dean of Students.  Then you needed to figure out which dorm you were going to work in.
Interview Questions: What was your reaction upon hearing there was an annual cross-dressing party.

title: Technical Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: Very friendly, in-person interview after email communication. I sent an email to the PI after hearing from an acquaintance that they would be searching for TAs, and after a couple of weeks of email correspondence, I had a phone interview with the PI. A few weeks later, I traveled to MIT to have an in-person interview with several members of the lab.
Interview Questions: As expected, challenges of research

title: Library Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: FIrst round was a phone interview. They emailed telling me they were interested and then we conducted a phone interview with 2 supervisors. Then a second live interview and tour, with introductions.
Interview Questions: What was a time you took initiative at work? What was the result?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: I was interviewed by Lab Supervisor first by phone and then a full day interview in Cambridge campus. The main focus was on technical side of the project they were looking for a researcher to work n. Not many behavioral questions was asked.
Interview Questions: Mainly technical

title: Administrative Assistant II Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: I was hired through a temporary agency for a part time position, had one phone interview and was asked to come in.  Then I grew within my department to a permanent position after 6 months.
Interview Questions: How long do you plan on staying around?

title: Postdoctoral Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: I applied for an advertized position and was short listed. I was interviewed on Skype as I was in Europe during that time. After the interview, email confirming my acceptance came and work permit documents were soon dispatached within 2 weeks. It took 1 month after administrative processing at US embassy for J1 visa
Interview Questions: where do you see yourself in next 5 years

title: Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at MIT in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: Applied for job posted end of April. Phone interview 2 weeks later, on-campus interview 2 weeks after that. Long interview on campus, about 6 hours, including a presentation for a just above entry-level position. It was several weeks before I heard a decision and I had to reach out to them. Was told by one employee that a decision would not be made for another week but received another reply from different employee same day saying they had selected someone. Hmm. Several months later I found out they didn't hire anyone. Would have liked a little more transparency...
Interview Questions: Question regarding student development theories. I had not been in grad school for over two years at this point and couldn't recall specific names or publications.

title: Research Scientist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at MIT (Boston, MA) in Apr 2014
Interview Descriptions: I came in to talk about a research scientist position. I gave a talk, met with people I would be working with, and heard a lot about the potential project. It was all pretty standard, people were nice. There were not many questions, more being talked at than questioned. Went out to dinner with the group, toured around the campus area where I would be working. The presentation was in a seminar room and involved some questioning, but just on past research.
Interview Questions: Are you willing to do this job?

title: Administrative Assistant II Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions: Easy to communicate with hiring team, very personable. Thorough, 3 step interview process beginning with support staff and ending with upper level faculty and administration. All my questions were answered.
Interview Questions: Don't recall

title: Assistant Professor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jan 2014
Interview Descriptions: Requirements included a one hour job talk with question and answer period afterwards, one on one interview with a current faculty member, and an interview with faculty search committee. After the process, I felt that the committee already had the right candidate in mind and needed to go through the motions with other candidates.
Interview Questions: What is future role of your field?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 6 months. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jan 2014
Interview Descriptions: I initially planned to take a course at MIT, but upon persistence, continued communication and great performance, I was able to get paid for conducting research immediately. I was not technically "interviewed"; it was rather a 6 month long process of staying in touch with and collaborating with (and doing free work for) my desired lab.
Interview Questions: My ten year plan. I had never had one, and so I had to devise one.

title: Human Resources Position Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions:
Pros:
-Speedy response after applying online.  I received a call for a phone screen about 1 week after applying online

-Was invited in for an in-person interview less than a week after the phone screen

-Interview was very informative and gave great insight to the culture and the people itself

-People in the department were extremely friendly


Cons:
-Was told by the recruiter that my salary expectations were within the range but was told during the in-person interview that they were not anywhere near their range

-The in-person interview with director was extremely long; almost half the work day

-Even after sending a thank you & checking in a week later, I never received any sort of response or follow up as to the status and whether or not they had filled the position with another candidate.  Very unprofessional, especially for an HR department.
Interview Questions: I wouldn't consider this the most difficult, but they did as how to handle certain employee situations (performance issues, compensation, etc)

title: Postdoctoral Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: Hiring process was very convenient. The interview was very technical and positive.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Dec 2013
Interview Descriptions: MIT media labs contacted me after I applied online. I was extremely surprised that they even considered me. I thought I was fortunate to get this response from them. I was scheduled to talk to a staff member from the lab from the biological side. She spoke to me and asked general questions about my PhD, my interests, computer vision and machine learning. I did OK and I didn't expect a callback as a result.
Interview Questions: What is my experience in biomedical/retinal computer vision?

title: Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at MIT in Dec 2013
Interview Descriptions: Like non-profits companies it does take a while to go through the process.  You need to be patient throughout the entire process.  Even when they offer the job you need to have the background check to make it official.  That process is a very long two weeks.
Interview Questions: They verbally offered job but not official until background check which takes 2 weeks.

title: Data Analyst/Project Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Dec 2013
Interview Descriptions: Very straight forward, quick and to-the-point. Typical questions were asked including current employment, why you would want to work for the company, three best qualities, three worst qualities, What would your friends and coworkers say about you. Hired upon completion of interview.
Interview Questions: What are your three best qualities

title: Postdoctoral Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Nov 2013
Interview Descriptions: I am a PhD from a local university in Boston.  I emailed the professor whose research area I am interested in.  Meanwhile,  I sent a hard copy of my CV and cover letter to his office.  After about 1 week, I got the email reply to have onsite interview with his lab.
Interview Questions: All questions are about technical problems. You will have to understand what you were doing clearly.

title: Associate Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: Excellent process.  Very professional.
Interview Questions: Nothing unexpected.

title: Development Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: Very long process. From the time I applied, it took 3 months to receive any information about the status of my application. I finally heard back and had a string of interviews (5-6) in one day.
Interview Questions: What is something new you learned today?

title: Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: just get invitation from the professor
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: no formal interview, just emailed the prof and met him to discuss the research
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at MIT in Sept 2013
Interview Descriptions: I had a brief chat with the senior recruiter who advised me that she would recommend they interview me. About 2 weeks later I was invited to interview with two different people in one on one situations. About a week and a half later I was invited to interview with the Dean. The interviews were quite casual and informative.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Technical Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview, followed by in-person interview.
Interview Questions: No crazy questions, they just wanted to make sure that I was qualified for the position and my resume checked out.

title: Senior Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions: Hiring processes at MIT can move slowly and often require several interviews.  This is because once someone becomes a part of the community, it is very difficult to get rid of them, so managers want to be really sure someone is a good match.  Sometimes managers don't even start looking at resumes until a position has been posted for a few weeks, so don't expect a quick response.  Expect to do more than one interview, not just with the hiring manager but with multiple stakeholders.  If you are applying for a job working directly with students, you may be interviewed by students, and their opinions are taken seriously.
Interview Questions: Everyone at MIT believes it is a very unique place.  So, if you act too confident that you will be successful in a job here because you have done a similar job somewhere else, that may be a turn-off.  Ask lots of questions and try to talk about how you would tailor your approach to the unique conditions that exist here.

title: Lab Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jul 2013
Interview Descriptions:
Applied online on MIT webiste.  First talked to a general HR recruiter.  Then set up a skype interview with the professor.  The interview was a bit bumpy, but I guess this person must have liked me very much because I ended up his first choice.  Just asked standard questions about research experience and career goals, management style, etc.
Then I got another pushy phone call from the HR person asking me to decide within a day whether to accept or not.  I did not like dealing with the HR department but I absolutely love my professor very much.
Interview Questions: What was the biggest challenge/problem you had to solve in your past position?

title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jul 2013
Interview Descriptions: Usual postdoc application process. I gave a 50 min presentation to the research group I applied to. Then met with the advisor, other postdocs and graduate students. I had several questions from all of them. I also had the opportunity to ask the postdocs privately about working with the advisor. A week after the presentation I got an offer to start working the next week.
Interview Questions: I was asked mostly about what experimental techniques I am familiar with. Also how experienced I was in writing custom instrument control software etc.

title: Manager of Communications & Special Projects Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at MIT in Jul 2013
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and was selected for a phone interview. From the phone interview I was brought in as a finalist for a 5+ hour interview (they provided breakfast and lunch). I was not selected but they did call to tell me directly, which I appreciated. It was a pleasant process and an impressive institution.
Interview Questions: Nothing difficult or scripted- It was all very conversational with the different parties involved. I was a little daunted by the 5 hour+ interview ahead of time, but it was an overall enjoyable process.

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview about past projects and future plans
Interview Questions: nothing difficult

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jun 2013
Interview Descriptions:
Every postdoc interview is different depending on the lab you are joining. I got the full day experience: 1h morning discussion with prof, 30min time-slots with other students and postdocs, lunch with prof, more 30 mins time-slots, 1 hour presentation of my research (30 min talk, and 30 min questions); debrief with prof and then finally dinner with 3 other postdocs. comprehensive enough, got offer next morning.

Do you prefer to work in a team or alone?
Lots of science specific questions.

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT in Jun 2013
Interview Descriptions: I was invited for a talk on my past projects. I presented my PhD thesis Project. Some professors, Students and Postdocs came to my talk and some of them asked questions about the application of my findings.
Interview Questions: Tell us about your findings. how can you compare your results and method with others.

title: Postdoctoral Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jun 2013
Interview Descriptions: Submit the CV and research statement. They will require the reference letter, usually at least 3 letters. After several weeks, I got the onsite interview, including  public presentation, talked with professors, talked with industrial coordinator, talked with students and other postdocs, lunch, dinner. It took one day and I got the response very soon.
Interview Questions: Academic questions about the research, thesis and paper

title: Production Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions: I emailed my resume was called within hours for interview. I interviewed with 4 people over 2 weeks and received an offer. They seemed to care more about character than skills. It's a kwirky company they are looking for very smart people who will in.
Interview Questions: They asked very personal questions that a little out of line.

title: Project Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in May 2013
Interview Descriptions: Single, very brief interview. The position was for basic data collection, so they were looking for basic competency. I interviewed a week after graduating college and was eager to accept an offer as soon as possible. My employer understood that I was overqualified for the position, and made it clear that this position would be a good stepping stone while I work to start my career.
Interview Questions: What are your long-term career goals?

title: Educational Technologist Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in May 2013
Interview Descriptions: This interview was for a newly formed department and was conducted among three separate teams across a three hour period. The teams varied from those I would be sharing an office with, to those who would be directing the department. There was a lot of nervous humor about working in an atmosphere that was constantly changing. They weren't joking. A lot of the job (which I accepted) has been "from the hip" for the past two years. Only recently have we begun formalizing our processes.
Interview Questions: How do you handle uncertain, changing goals?

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions: I was first contacted and had a brief phone screen that lasted approximately 20 minutes.  They asked me a few basic questions about my interest in the position, my prior experiences, and my salary expectations.  I was invited in for an in person interview by email the following week, and I met with the associate director and director of the office I was applying to.  Both interviewers were very friendly, and mainly wanted to know what skills I thought would be most valuable and how I believed my previous experience would lend itself to this position.
Interview Questions: What three skills would be more important in this position?

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at MIT (San Diego, CA) in Apr 2013
Interview Descriptions: Consisted with one phone interview, one on-site interview, and multiple follow-up phone interviews. During the main on-site interview, many random questions were asked. It seemed like there was no specific structure of the interview. However, most of the questions was about research in general and domain knowledge.
Interview Questions: Design a research that you wanted to conduct by assuming that there would unlimited resources.

title: Postdoctoral Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Apr 2013
Interview Descriptions: Send curriculum vitae and interview via Skype and send some supporting documents such as papers, PhD dissertation, and so on. And waited for 1 week and got an offer, and I took it.
Interview Questions: Just technical things related to previous research based on prepared slides for interview. Questions were focused on practical skills for me.

title: PhD Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 5 months. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Mar 2013
Interview Descriptions: I had an interview with the professor I ended up working for. I discussed my research interests and previous work experience. I also discussed potential projects I could be involved in during my Phd.
Interview Questions: What was your previous research experience?

title: PhD Graduate Student, Biology Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Feb 2013
Interview Descriptions: You meet around five or six professors and talk about your research, and ask questions about their research. Being able to carry out scientific conversations and talk to them about their research is necessary.
Interview Questions: What difficulties did you face in your project/research and how did you overcome it?

title: Communications Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Feb 2013
Interview Descriptions: It involved several directors asking questions about my previous experience and how it related to the position. It was about 90 minutes. There were no boiler plate questions that hiring managers tend to run with.
Interview Questions: How does your previous experience relate?

title: BMS Operator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Feb 2013
Interview Descriptions: When I arrived my current boss and a lady from HR were already ready to start the interview process. Seeing as I always show 20 minutes early for any interview I was shocked and pleased that they were all ready to go. We sat in a conference room and they proceeded to go over my past work experience and knowledge of the job. Interview all in all took about 20 min and went very well. Two days later I received a call from HR asking to come in for a second interview the following week with the same people plus another supervisor. Again, I arrived 20 min early and they were ready to get started. I had the same interview and got a call that night that with an offer for the position!
Interview Questions: Why I think I'm best for the job.

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at MIT in Feb 2013
Interview Descriptions:
I applied for Mechanical Engineering department for Master degree. 

I got email for scheduling Skype interview from the faculty and next week I had interview with the faculty.

The faculty interviewer is the one I referred on my SOP as whom I want work with.

But he told me that that was just general interview for whole departmental level, not just for his lab.

He told me that they don't usually interview like this for Master applicant in their department but policy was changed from that year.

The interview was really casual around 30 mins interview in very casual atmosphere.

I just briefly talked about my prior research experiences and he asked some questions.

It took more than 2 months to be declined and thought I was on the wait list.

Hope this would be helpful for you guys!
Interview Questions: When is the most frustrated moment in your research experience?

title: Master of Finance Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at MIT
Interview Descriptions:
Normal application process with essays and interviews
Interviews are all fit questions such as why this program? Why you? What's your career goal? Give me an example when you lead a team. Give me an example when you are a team player.
Interview Questions: Not really. What courses/professors you are interested in. Be sure to get familiar with the course name.

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: Very technical; spoke everyone to the team. Be very good with your technical papers. They ask you very detailed mathematicalk questions about your work, however it depends on the kind of work you do. Both math & value of your work are important.
Interview Questions: Explain the value of your last publication and what it does?

title: Research Scientist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: Very hard and extensive. with technical questions on every part of my background. It first started on optical setups and then progressed to device physics questions and more so on nanotechnology and chemistry.
Interview Questions: What is your best paper

title: Industrial Liaison Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at MIT in Oct 2012
Interview Descriptions: I got a phone interview from the HR first. It was short, about 10-15 minutes. She just checked some points on the resume and gave some explaination about the position. Then she scheduled site interview with me immediately. The site interview ended after only one question, do you need visa sponsorship?
Interview Questions: do you need visa sponsorship?

title: Fiscal Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Oct 2012
Interview Descriptions: First round interviews were in-person with manager and several team members. The second round was in a group setting with the whole team. Very detailed interview questions about skills and experience. Also met with unit director. Interviews were followed by reference checks.
Interview Questions: How have you added value to a team, both quantitative and qualitative.

title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Sept 2012
Interview Descriptions: Interview with PI and then second interview with whole lab. Was asked a range of questions, ranging from career objectives to details about SQL programming. PI was very relaxed and happy to help me get to the US. The culture of the lab was relaxed and it was important to be considered part of the team.
Interview Questions: Presentation of previous research and being grilled

title: Technical Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Aug 2012
Interview Descriptions:
I was hired for a biomedical research position in a professor's lab. My hiring process seemed very informal, especially compared with my interviews for industry positions and former job at a company. A week after applying, the PI contacted me, and we had an agreeable conversation over the phone. About a week later, he arranged for some other folks in the lab to meet me, show me around and take me out for lunch. None of the questions were very difficult and I was given the impression that an offer was likely given that I was invited in in the first place. Things moved quickly with an offer; I received a verbal offer from the PI, and he asked for my thoughts, got a sense that I seemed likely to accept, and sent me a formal offer a week later. I was working in the lab 2 weeks after my in-person visit. The process was curiously simple, and I would caution others not to assume this is a reliable pattern from lab to lab.

On the downside of "informal", starting at the lab was a bit awkward. On the plus side, a grad student did take initiative to help me get situated, and someone had put together a welcome packet- more than my others before me had gotten. But there really wasn't much by way of official "orientation" or a clear message or timeline concerning what I needed to do to appropriately integrate into the lab.
Interview Questions: Nothing stands out. Nobody really went for the tough questions.

title: Administrative Assistant II Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jun 2012
Interview Descriptions: I came in through a recruiter and everything happened very fast. I met with the office manager and the front desk admin for about an hour. Two days later I came back and interviewed the three managers I would be supporting and the process was straightforward. The next day I had an offer and I started the next week.
Interview Questions: Describe your previous work experience and how would you currently manage a difficult-to-manage employee?

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jun 2012
Interview Descriptions: GRE, TOEFL and application, with a phone interview. The process is quite similar to other university application in general. Although the references from your college might play a good part.
Interview Questions: how much experience i have in field i applied for

title: Undergraduate Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions: Earlier in the Spring, I emailed a bunch of labs in the Media Lab for a UROP for the summer. I received very few responses, one of which was from the lab I worked in, which told me they didn't have any open positions, but they would email me if anything came up. The last day before the UROP application deadline, I emailed them again, and they had an open position. I went in that day, and they gave me the job after a few talks with the professor and the grad student I would be working with. So I got the position.
Interview Questions: What do you know about big data?

title: Postdoctoral Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Feb 2012
Interview Descriptions: It starts with the phone interview 2 week ahead of time. then on site interview starts with talk with the PI. followed by 45 min presentation plus individual meetings with 5 people wihtin the group
Interview Questions: Which project is the one best reflecting your skill set and capability?

title: Student Programmer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Bloomington, IN) in Feb 2012
Interview Descriptions: I was applying for a student position at MIT. I was interviewed by a graduate who worked in cognitive science. I was in high school at the time and had no prior interview experience. I thought the whole experience was a bit awkward; we didn't find too much common ground to talk about.
Interview Questions: Why MIT?

title: Postdoctoral Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions: Gave a 1 hour talk and spent the day speaking with graduate students and postdocs from the lab, around 30 - 45 mins per person. Lunch and dinner was also spent with lab members. Spent an hour with the principle investigator (PI) before the talk, and interacted with the PI during the presentation. Was offered a position at the end of the day, but took a month to consider it and accept.
Interview Questions: Was asked questions during my presentation directly related to my graduate work.

title: Postdoctoral Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions: I was asked to visit the lab and give a formal presentation. I had interacted with the group members one on one and went for dinner with a postdoc from the lab
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Technical Associate - Sponsored Research Staff (Temporary) Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions: I spoke with the supervisor while a fellow lab researcher listened in, and later the director of the lab group stopped by very briefly. They mostly asked me questions about my technical background based off of my submitted resume, and there was also a simple, open-ended question about the experimental problem the job entailed to assess my thoughts and approaches. Later, I was shown an experiment in progress similar to what I would be working on. The interview was mostly informational in nature, and took 30 minutes total.
Interview Questions: Suppose the driver of a push-button ignition vehicle finds his/her vehicle is suddenly accelerating out of control. What would their first reaction be? What improvements need to be made to today's systems to address this?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Dec 2011
Interview Descriptions: Application for admission to graduate school needs to be completed online. It requires GRE score, 3 letters of recommendation (minimum), TOEFL score, SOP (statement of purpose). The deadline for submitting the online application is around December 1 for mechanical engineering department. Once the application is submitted, it is reviewed by the admission committee. If successful in getting admission into graduate school, one can talk to professors in their field of interest to join their group as a research assistant.
Interview Questions: Getting admitted into graduate school is the hardest part

title: Graduate Student Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Oct 2011
Interview Descriptions: Wrote an email with my cv; then skype interview about what they're doing and what I'm going to do there; had to provide 3 references that were checked; got applied after references were spoken to
Interview Questions: I knew one person there that was interviewed before; I told him that I could conduct some research on a different university. He obviously told them about it, so they asked me what I would do there and why I would prefer to work here.

title: Development Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Sept 2011
Interview Descriptions: I was brought in for a temp to perm position. This job required you to be personable, so they just wanted to talk and get to know me.  The ladies I worked with were very easy to talk to, offered me water or coffee, and generally made me feel very comfortable. The interview lasted about an hour in which they asked about my resume and past experiences and how they were applicable to the position.
Interview Questions: They did not ask any of the awkward interview questions. Everything was very straightforward. They asked about my resume and past experiences and how they were applicable to the position.

title: Administrative Support Staff Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Sept 2011
Interview Descriptions: Standard interview questions and process. There were no surprises, they asked basic questions relevant to the job and the interview was long enough and casual enough for them to get a feel of whether I would be a good fit for the culture of the department, in addition to having the skills to do the job. If you made it to the interview stage then you already passed a lot of hurdles and it's mostly about personality and how you come off.
Interview Questions: Describe a time when you handled a difficult work situation. Where do you see yourself in 5 years?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jun 2011
Interview Descriptions: Easy get-to-know you interview process,   It was informative.  It told me about what the project was about.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Undergraduate Research Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jun 2011
Interview Descriptions: The phone interview is great!!! He asked me about my experience and different programs I can use. Overall, it's not a bad interview.
Interview Questions: How would you handle the project if you work independently?

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jun 2011
Interview Descriptions: Two interviews, one with the boss, one with coworkers. I never met or was screened by anyone in HR. There was also a long pause between interviews. I found it unusual that the interview and hiring process was not managed by HR in any way. It is difficult to provide useful information here because now that I've been at MIT for a while, I know that each department will conduct their own interviews and they will vary widely.
Interview Questions: Lots of standard behavioral interview questions and questions about my past experience.

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jun 2011
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was slow, but my department was thorough.  I had a phone interview, in person interview, then a meeting with the program director.  MIT has a  fragmented HR department, so it was difficult to get answers to questions that were HR related.  Also, it was over a month between when I interviewed and got an offer for the position.
Interview Questions: How would you deal with working in a small office environment?

title: Technical Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in May 2011
Interview Descriptions:
I first met the postdoc I was hired to work for at a lab meeting at Children's Hospital Boston. I was recruited by a PI at MGH, and she openly protested and offered me a position on the spot. 

I had a formal interview and another post-doc decided he wanted to have me work for him as well, so I ended up having two separate projects to work for full time (in hindsight, this was a mistake). 

The interview itself was pretty informal. I was asked about what research areas I was interested in, what my goals were, and the usual interview banter. The PI of the lab later told me that one of my recommenders (I didn't know it at the time, but a collaborating PI) said he'd "have to be insane not to hire me". Lesson learned: never underestimate the value/power of what others say about you (both positive, and negative).
Interview Questions: What is your life's ambition

title: Technical Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at MIT in Mar 2011
Interview Descriptions: Good communication between the HR department and the job poster and the candidates. Affirmative action is in full force at MIT, making it particularly difficult for highly qualified white male candidates to get positions, which is unusual since the gender ratio at MIT is very even and about 80% of the population is not white.
Interview Questions: what are your long term goals?

title: Postdoctoral Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Mar 2011
Interview Descriptions: send my CV directly to the Professor. I had three phone interviews in the four months of the process - I applied in March, got the offer in July, and started working in August.
Interview Questions: I told them that I had another offer and needed time to decide and they ask me the other company's name.

title: Administrative Assistant II Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Feb 2011
Interview Descriptions:
Rule #1: Sign up with a staffing agency. Find out what agencies the school you want to work at utilizes and sign up with them. This was the key component of getting the great position that I have. The agency will help you tweak your resume, etc. Working with them really serves as a pre-interview.
  
MIT is looking for people who know their stuff. Make sure you have some background in Academia and emphasize your ability to work cross-departmentally. Eventually everyone works together so you have to be a team player.
Interview Questions: Do you really expect to make between x & y dollars?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Boston, MA) in Jan 2011
Interview Descriptions: Via Mail.  Inquired if any positions available, specified skills.  Talked on telephone with potential employer and got an offer in the mail a couple of weeks later.  Very easy
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Engineering Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jan 2011
Interview Descriptions: People were very nice. Had one on one interviews with about 10 people.
Interview Questions: What are things that you do outside of work?

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: The process took 3 days. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jan 2011
Interview Descriptions: Regular grad school applications, followed by a weekend long interview.  Met with three professors for individual interviews.  The questions are related to your past academic and job experience, and mainly research.  The professors tell you about their research so you can learn about what the program offers and ask them questions.  You also get to spend time with current students and meet more professors over lunch and dinner.  Overall very fun.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your research and use a piece of a paper to draw diagrams.

title: Engineering Interview
Application Type: The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Jul 2010
Interview Descriptions:
First I was called in for 1:1 interview with the professor. It still consisted of me giving a presentation but only to him. Then we talked about my experieces etc. Overall, it was just a nice conversation.
Then he said that he'd like me to come in and give an official presentation to the whole lab, and that was ok as well. After that there was a lunch and dinner interview with the lab members, which was still just talking...
Interview Questions: why do you want to join our lab?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. I interviewed at MIT in Jul 2010
Interview Descriptions: Very specific to department and lab. Mine involved talking to all principal investigators regardless of if I would work on projects with them. Slow hiring process - IT has to interview a certain number of people even if they want you.
Interview Questions: If you mention skills in CV be prepared to talk about them!

title: Executive Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Boston, MA) in Jun 2010
Interview Descriptions: Experience, management style, personality and past salary matter.  Especially past salary.
Interview Questions: salary requirements

title: Executive Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at MIT (East Cambridge, MA) in May 2010
Interview Descriptions: I contacted my colleague for which a position was available in his department. I submitted my resume and cover letter via email. We spoke on the phone and set up a time to meet to discuss my desires. We then met t talk about my impending layoff and desire to transfer within the company. A second interview was then set up with him (the hiring manager) and the supervisor. It was pleasant, informative, congenial, and I felt I was a good match for the job. At the end of the interview, I was informed that a decision would be made within two weeks. This time had gone by, so I emailed my colleague to inquire about the status. He informed me that they were making an offer to another candidate, but if she didn't accept it I would be considered a finalist.
Interview Questions: How would you handle a difficult situation where a director asked you for your immediate help with travel, and you had an imminent deadline on a presentation quickly approaching.

title: Office Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in May 2010
Interview Descriptions: The interviewer is very friendly. Personal attitude is a critical criteria during the selection process. I am a easy-going person and I can get along with most people. They are looking for person who pays attention to details, responsible, able to work independently.
Interview Questions: What field-related experience do you have?

title: Quantitative Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in May 2010
Interview Descriptions: It was an online application and telephone interview
Interview Questions: What is the yield of a treasury bond

title: HVAC Technician Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at MIT in Apr 2010
Interview Descriptions: Oral interviews, where you are asked about previous job experience and reason for leaving. and the candidate is asked why he/she wants to work for MIT. the tell you what is expected of the candidates, and what the job entails.
Interview Questions: There is also writen technical quize regarding his/her professional trades

title: UROP Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Nov 2009
Interview Descriptions: Interviewing for an UROP position at MIT is relatively easy. I first look up the professors who has research topics that interests me. Then I either emailed them or talk to them in person to express my interest in becoming a UROP intern at their lab. Next, I scheduled interviews with them. The interview itself is very lax in its atmosphere. The professor just want to you if you are really interested in their research and if you have any background skill that's necessary in their research. For many of the UROP positions though, you don't even need to have much skill in their research area since it's often cutting edge anyways.
Interview Questions: Considering your normal school work load, how much time can you commit to this project?

title: Student Services Interview
Application Type: The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Aug 2009
Interview Descriptions: presentation, panels, one on one with an office head. Be yourself--if you don't mind not getting a job. Pay attention to the climate of the office and how everyone interacts. I
Interview Questions:
Walk me through your resume....
Describe a conflict within a team and how I handled it.

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Apr 2009
Interview Descriptions: I went to MIT for my undergraduate degree, so the application process was fairly straightforward. I emphasized heavily my hands-on research and internship experience, which I thought would be valuable going into experimental research. I did not receive any feedback on my application packet, just an acceptance letter. I was in close contact with faculty in my prospective department throughout the application process.
Interview Questions: There were no particularly difficult questions on the application; it was a straightforward graduate admissions package.

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: The process took 3 days. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Mar 2009
Interview Descriptions: Based on prior presentations at conferences, one on one interview and advisor recommendations.
Interview Questions: How did you decide on studying physics?

title: Science/Engineering Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Lexington, MA) in Feb 2009
Interview Descriptions:
I gave a 45 minute presentation on my current work, then met with 3 separate individuals for 1:1 interviews.  The interviews were respectful give and takes where we had opportunity to discuss my work and the company's activities.  The questions were appropriate and not terribly hard.

The HR department is very disorganized.  I only had 2-day notice of my interview, and that a presentation was expected.
Interview Questions: They asked about technical details related to my work.  The questions were all specific to my research work.

title: PhD Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Feb 2009
Interview Descriptions: Interview about prior research experience and academic interest. Discussions about future funding opportunities in various labs affiliated with the PhD program.
Interview Questions: Discuss: how the brain processes information.

title: Open Postdoctoral Applications Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at MIT (Cambridge, MA) in Dec 2008
Interview Descriptions:
initial contact at conference, then e-mail application with resume. e-mail reply back with request for letters of recommendation. 1 hr presentation about research done, 1 hour interview with Pi about reasearch done, ongoing research in the lab and my research interests. 1:1 or 1:3 meetings with alsmost all lab members.
final meeting with PI, positive vibe, should let know my project interests and put that on paper.
e-mail correspondence about when and how to start
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in our laboratory?

title: Engineering Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at MIT (Cincinnati, OH) in Nov 2008
Interview Descriptions: My interviewer was really nice and was very open to taking questions and talked about his own experience at MIT and how it helped him. The questions were interesting and thought provoking, so be sure to get a lot of sleep beforehand so as to be clear-thinking. He did take some notes as I talked.
Interview Questions: If the government gave you a project to lead how would you assemble your team?

title: Technical Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at MIT (Boston, MA) in May 2008
Interview Descriptions: Hiring and interview happened informally at a conference and then at MIT
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Web Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at MIT in Mar 2007
Interview Descriptions:
This was an internal referral, so I was interviewing with people I was mostly familiar with already.  I was interviewed by one person and then he was joined by a colleague for the second half of the interview. The interview process was fairly casual in terms of attire and also how they approached asking me questions. They may have discussed questions in advance but it seemed like most questions were improvised. Most of the time they diverged from a written list of questions.

A few days later I was interviewed by a group ("the team") in a small office. There were 5 people present asking me questions and I didn't really know any of them. The group interview was not structured and was quite chaotic. I was able to ask them questions and found myself leading the interview at points. Later on it became more of a free for all when we got onto a hot button topic. I found the group trying to steer my responses in their direction (to their point of view) , I mostly agreed with them but chose to hold my ground. Based on their responses I realized that this position was not a good match. I later told the two main hiring managers that the position wasn't a good fit.

The Information Technology group there is interesting, the culture is fairly laid back and flexible. Many people work unusual schedules and are able to come in later and work later or work half days. Some people are able to work one day from home. This is a big part of why they're able to retain employees. The atmosphere is more artsy/newsroom than a Dilbert cube farm. People work hard but are still fairly chatty and they tend to congregate in the break room at lunch time. No one wears suits and very few people dress up. If you're wearing something nice, you either have a presentation or you're headed to a job interview. Overdressed people draw suspicion.
Interview Questions: Why do you want this job?
